text.headline: Marching a Battery of Field Artillery from Ft. Sill to Ft. Riley in 1905
text.text:
"THIS MAP CONTAINS MORE USEFUL INFORMATION THAN ANY MAP THAT HAS BEEN RECEIVED AT THIS HEADQUARTERS SINCE HE HAS BEEN IN COMMAND" -- Division Commander

Index to some of the various complications of Fulton Q.C. Gardner, 2nd Lt. A. C. [Artillery Corps] QM, [Quarter Master], Comm [Commissary], Eng. Off., Summary Court, Adjutant, etc. etc. Fellow of the Ancient & Honorable Society of Knockers, etc. etc. Ex officio, candidate for Perry's North Pole Expedition, and author of many brochures on how to tie up QM & Comm's papers, etc - etc - etc

The march [of men, about 200 horses, guns and other equipment of a Battery of Field Artillery] was to be about 400 miles in length, mostly through small towns in regard to which there was no information available as to the availability of oats, hay, meat, wood, etc. It was to take place in November and December (midwinter)...From such poor maps as were available ...we planned our route and I wrote letters to the Postmasters of each town we were to pass through asking them to return to me ... the approximate amounts of hay, oats, wood, meat, etc., if any, that were available there for purchase...During the march it was quite cold. The water in the canvas bucket in my tent froze solid at night. In each town we passed through several dogs followed us out of town.

text.headline: Ft. Sill
text.text:
wood allowance = 1/6 cord per man per mo.<br> Contract price at Ft. Sill,/A>,
For oats = $1.23 per 100 lbs
For hay = $0.40
For beef = 5 7/10 cents per pound
For wood = about $4.00 per cord

text.headline: Apache, Nov 4
text.text:
3 E & 17 N Sill

Fresh beef 115 lbs $6.32

[pop 1616 in 2000]

text.headline: Anadarko, Nov 5
text.text:
12 N & 7 E apache

Fresh Beef 180 lbs $9.00

[pop 6645 in 2000]

text.headline: Skiddy, Dec 2
text.text:
1 store pop. 50.
a good camp 1 mi. North of P.O. in Clark' Creek
also "             " 1/2 " south "                                      "
very hard to get hay and oats . Write to
Mr. Schmedermon, a farmer & perhaps he
can supply forage. P. Mahony & Sons are
too high priced & poor stuff.
very hilly today.

text.headline: Fort Reno, Nov 8 - 18
text.text: 30 N and 12 E of Anadarko

text.headline: Hennessey, Nov. 17
text.text:
Hennessey (2500) fine town
Write to Mr. J. A. Felt, Postmaster & he will arrange everything)
Camp at Fair Grounds. Use city mains for water. 1/2 m East town.
Roads fair today. In places heavy with mud when
wet; elsewhere heavy with sand when dry.
All supplies can be purchased on few days notice
but only wood meat & hay on short notice.
For last 2 days railroad practically straight from town to town.

text.headline: Kingfisher, Nov. 18
text.text:
6E and 21 N of Reno 

(3,000)

 Camp at Fair grounds - fine [???] - see mayor. 1/2 mile East of town on John's Creek.
water near at stream.
all purchases in town.
all roads good today.
No water en route.
wood scarce in town but may be purchased from brickyards
city has waterworks.
[pop. 4633 in 2000]

text.headline: Enid, Nov 20
text.text:
pop 13000

Write to Mr. Whiting, Postmaster - very obliging.

Camp at Fair Grounds - 1/2 mi South of town.

Use city mains for water -

Roads very good -

All supplies can be purchased in town on short notice 

"Tanks" and camp sites en route frequently.

[pop 49,379 in 2010. Founded 1893]

text.headline: Pond Creek, Nov 21
text.text:
pop 1500

Write to Mr. Ferry, Co?? Vidette Office.
Camp just south of town. Can use city water
or "tank" near.
Roads today about 3/4 good, others somewhat sandy.
All supplies can be purchased in town
on one days notice except wood. Had [???]
to use Railroad ties.
Many "tanks" & ponds & campsites en route.

[pop 858 in 2010]

text.headline: Renfrow, Nov. 22
text.text:
pop. 300, ?? 30 [?] stores - good little town.
Write to Postmaster or Mr. A. S. Jeel.
Good roads today everywhere
Many good camps & water.
About one days notice necessary 
to get hay & oats in town.

text.headline: Caldwell, Nov. 23 [Thanksgiving in 1905?]
text.text:
pop. 2500 - plenty of stores.
gumbo roadsnewly worked, bad in wet weather.
Camp near stand pipe in west part of town. Get permission from Mayor, use city mains for stock.
Do not patronize I. X. Glover.
[pop 1068 in 2010]

text.headline: Wellington, Nov. 25
text.text:
good big town
Write to Col. Garver, fine old man.
Roads today good dirt roads - pretty muddy where shown in wet weather.
Camp on Mr. Sykes place near Poor Farm.
water stock near at Slate Creek -
wood etc purchased O.K. -
Many good camping places found en route.
[pop 8172 in 2010]

text.headline: Peck, Nov 25
text.text:
pop 300.
grain elevator, write to J. K. Bell for hay, oats & wood. He owns elevator & may need 1 days notice.
Roads today very good; - dirt
Many good fenced camping grounds -
water at River.

text.headline: Wichita, Nov 27
text.text:
pop 35,000, large area.
roads today very muddy but many
recently worked.
Camp at South Side River Park, water from River near -
wood very difficult to buy. Do not patronize J. H. Turner.
Write to Capt. Downing, photographer, Main Street. He will make arrangements
[pop 382,368 in 2010; metro area 630,721 in 2011; incorporated 1870]

text.headline: Newton, Nov 28
text.text:
pop. 7000
main road is a continuation of Lawrence Ave.
in Wichita, also a road either 1 mi E or 1 mi W
of this road. The E road goes straight to
Newton and is good in wet weather. It hits
2 mi E of center of town of Newton but is
O.K. for those enroute to Peabody -
22 telephone wires on main road, 12 on W. road
& none on E road.
Hay oats and wood can be purchased in
town from Pruit's Feed store.
Write Mr.Col. Haesington or Mr.
Kaufman for information etc.
[pop 19,132 in 2010]

text.headline: Peabody, nov. 29
text.text:
pop. 1000 2 feed stores
roads today gumbo, good except in wet
weather.
City water works but not available in
outskirts of town.
Camp at Santa Fe Stockyards south of
town about 1/4 mile on S. Fe tracks.
Water in stream near.
Write to W. A. Sterling the grain
dealer about camp or to Post master.
[pop. 1210 in 2010]

text.headline: Marion, Nov 30
text.text:
2500 pop. plenty of stores,
gumbo road, good when dry.
Camp in ballpark in East part of town use city mains for stock.
Write to Mr. O. C. Billings, the Post master
about all arrangements.
wood purchased from Mr. Fisch, in country [??]
[pop. 1927 in 2010. Named for Francis Marion]

text.headline: Herington, Dec. 1
text.text:
pop 1500
But one feed store (Herington Mills) and
that unable [??] to stock the Q.M.
Camp in ball park in North end of town
ask mayor. plenty of water in ponds [??]
for horses & men.
fine roads today. gumbo frozen

text.headline: Skiddy, Dec 2
text.text:
1 store pop. 50.
a good camp 1 mi. North of P.O. in Clark' Creek
also "             " 1/2 " south "                                      "
very hard to get hay and oats . Write to
Mr. Schmedermon, a farmer & perhaps he
can supply forage. P. Mahony & Sons are
too high priced & poor stuff.
very hilly today.
